item.title: Latex Suite Instructions
item.description: r: This indicates that the snippet's trigger should be treated as a regular expression. Regular expressions allow for more complex pattern matching, enabling you to define triggers that recognize various inputs rather than a fixed string. m: This denotes Math mode. When m is included in the options, the snippet will only be activated when you are inside a LaTeX math block (e.g., between $ or $$ delimiters). A: This stands for Auto-expansion. If A is present, the snippet will expand automatically as soon as the trigger text is typed. If A is omitted, you'll need to press Tab (or the assigned expansion key) after typing the trigger to activate the snippet.

Retractions are the topological analogues of projection operators in other parts of mathematics.

item.title: Lee Exercise 1.1
item.description:
The locally Euclidean property of a Topological ManifoldTopological Manifold means that for each we can find an open subset containing an open subset , and
a homeomorphismhomeomorphism Exercise 1.1Show that equivalent definitions of manifolds are obtained if instead of allowing to be homeomorphic to any open subset of , we require it to be homeomorphic to an open ball in , or to itself.proof: Assume that for each we have: an open subset containing an open ball a homeomorphism Then, since every open ball of is an open subset of we have the existence of an open subset of that is homeomorphic to Assume that for each we have: an open subset containing an open subset , and a homeomorphism
We now must show that there is a set homeomorphic to some open ball in . By definition of openness in , there exists an open ball around such that This implies Note that is a homeomorphism, and the restriction of this homeomorphism to is also a homeomorphism. As a result, has an open neighborhood . is open since homeomorphisms map open sets to open sets. See Continuous iff Inverse Preserves Open SetsContinuous iff Inverse Preserves Open Sets. Thus is homeomorphic to an open ball () in . Assume that for each we have: an open subset containing a homeomorphism Then, since is an open subset of we have the existence of an open subset of that is homeomorphic to Assume that for each we have: an open subset containing an open subset , and a homeomorphism From the proof for open balls, we have the existence of a homeomorphism from to an open ball , and any open ball in Euclidean space is homeomorphic to the whole space. In conclusion, is homeomorphic to .

A vector space over a field is a non-empty set together with a binary operation and a binary function that satisfy eight axioms. The elements of are called vectorsvectors and the elements of are called scalars
The binary operation, called vector addition or simply addition assigns to any two vectors and in a third vector in which is commonly written as and is called the sum of these two vectors.
The binary function, called scalar multiplication assigns to any scalar in and any vector in another vector in which is denoted To have a vector space, the eight following axioms must be satisfied for every and

item.title: Stereographic Projection
item.description:
#Complex_Analysis Definition:
If the complex planecomplex plane is identified with the plan with the and axis corresponding to the real and imaginary axis respectively, the transformation takes on a simple geometric meaning. Writing then based on the coordinates calculated in the Riemann sphereRiemann sphere we have that and this means that the points and are in a straight line. The projection from which touches the point on the sphere and in the plane is called a stereographic projection. The context will make it clear whether the stereographic projection is regarded as a mapping from (the unit sphere) to the extended complex planeextended complex plane or vice versa.Remarks:
A stereographic projection transforms every straight linestraight line in the complex plane into a circle on which passes through the pole and the converse is also true. More generally, any circle on the sphere corresponds to a circle or a straight line in the .

item.title: Same Homology Groups and Fundamental Group but Not Homotopy Equivalent
item.description:
Show that and have the same homology groups and fundamental groups but a different homotopy type. Rotman Exercise 9.46proof:By Reduced Homology of Wedge SumReduced Homology of Wedge Sum we have that And by Kunneth FormulaKunneth Formula we have Thus by Sandwiched Zeros of Exact SequenceSandwiched Zeros of Exact Sequence we have In order for to be non-trivial, both terms must be non-trivial (in this case since they are spheres), thus we get Thus the four cases are (0,0), (1,0), (0,2), (1,2) and we get
By Fundamental Group of Products is Product of Fundamental GroupsFundamental Group of Products is Product of Fundamental Groups we have With the second to last isomorphism coming from Sn Fundamental GroupSn Fundamental Group (coming from n-1 connectedness of Snn-1 connectedness of Sn)
Then by Seifert-Van KampenSeifert-Van Kampen we have again by n-1 connectedness of Snn-1 connectedness of Sn.Suppose for purpose of contradiction that they are homotopy equivalent. Then the universal cover of looks like the real number line with the higher spheres wedged at each integer
which is homotopy equivalent to On the other hand, the universal cover of is equivalent to which is homotopy equivalent to which has trivial homology on dimension three and thus can't be homotopy equivalent to . Similarly, because it covers the space and is simply connected?
Then by Homotopy Equivalent Spaces Have Homotopy Equivalent Universal CoversHomotopy Equivalent Spaces Have Homotopy Equivalent Universal Covers, since the universal covers are not homotopy equivalent, neither are the spaces.
item.guid: Math-Encyclopedia/Algebraic Topology/Theorems/Sajan/Same Homology Groups and Fundamental Group but Not Homotopy Equivalent.md
